newsitem.title: USA: US, China poultry talks delayed - US industry.
newsitem.headline: US, China poultry talks delayed - US industry.

text.p: U.S. Poultry and Egg Export Council President James Sumner said Friday a meeting between U.S. and Chinese officials in Beijing on blocked U.S. poultry exports would likely be delayed until Tuesday.
Sumner told Reuters that logistical problems had caused the delay in the meeting which a USDA official had previously said would be held on Monday.
Sumner said he remained confident that the stoppage would be "nipped in the bud."
A joint statement by Sumner's organization and the National Broiler Council (NBC) said there had been little or no impact on trade so far from the stoppage.
USDA Dairy, Livestock and Poultry Division Director John Reddington said Thursday China had held up poultry meat imports from 10 U.S. states because of concerns over avian influenza.
"We understand that the U.S. government will confirm to the Chinese that avian influenza is not a problem in the U.S.," the two poultry groups said in a joint statement.
"Hopefully Chinese concerns will be satisfied before any impact is felt on trade," the statement, released at the end of the NBC annual conference outside Washington said.
